Charles, there are many ways insurers can lower costs, and the point of this article is to point out that increasing the number of insurers will give them less leverage to negotiate lower payments to doctors and hospitals.

Insurers can also keep costs low by having higher deductibles and restricting what is covered. Another way insurers can control costs is by attempting to select healthy customers that are least likely to pose risk.

This is standard operating procedure with most kinds of insurance, with insurers actually refusing to provide coverage - be it life insurance, flood insurance or until recently, health insurance to people who represented great risk.

Even with laws preventing insurers from discriminating against sick people, there is no motive to actually provide high levels of service to people who are going to cost more than they pay in premiums. Thus the need for some serious regulations requiring insurers to cover the same set of services or have insurers get extra reimbursement for taking sicker people, as is done in Europe.

I don't know what rules, if any, there are regarding deductibles, but via deductibles, insurers can effectively charge more to people with preexisting conditions.

In short, I think your hopes for competition providing greater value at lower cost are somewhat misguided.

Your list of proposals is interesting. I like the idea of 28% on tax benefit from deductions but I would not make it a limit; I would apply a flat 28% for all taxpayers. That would raise less money, of course, because nearly everyone would get a lower tax bill, but I still like the idea. Maybe make it 25% or 20% instead of 28%.

Note that if there is a flat maximum dollar limit on the tax benefit from deductions and if capital gains and dividends are taxed as ordinary income, the Alternative Minimum Tax could be repealed as it would no longer be needed. Even Buffet's proposal would no longer be needed.

With regard to your capital gains proposal, my preference would be to treat long term capital gains as ordinary income--same for dividends, same for carried interest.

I like increasing the income tax rates for the top 2%, but would not object (though it would hit me hard) to just letting all the Bush tax cuts expire. I lived through the Clinton taxes once and I could do it again. The country was better off then and I think it would be better off again.

I propose that the payroll taxes not be capped (true for Hospital Insurance already), and be treated as part of income taxes, i.e., income taxes would be reduced dollar for dollar for payroll taxes. This would wipe out much of your proposals, even much of the higher proposals I've made.

Since the cold water fills the tub in half the time as the hot, it must flow twice as fast. So the two together will have a total flow that's three times that of the hot water.

Since the hot water alone fills the tub in an hour, a flow three times as fast will fill it in one third the time, which is 20 minutes.
